message: It is shameful that the first action of the Republican majority in the 115th Congress will be to advance a rules package gutting the independent Office of Congressional Ethics.  In the dark of night, in a secret vote, the majority breached public trust by disempowering the sole independent investigatory body holding lawmakers accountable for ethics violations.  This action exposes Republicans’ campaign pledge of ‘drain the swamp’ as absolute parody.  Furthermore, instead of protecting American families from the devastating effects of gun violence, House Republicans have responded to last year's historic Democratic sit-in by proposing potentially unconstitutional punishments for Members who participate in similar actions in the future. This is unacceptable, and Democrats will not be intimidated out of fiercely advocating for policies that save American lives.  The Republican rules package includes brazen assaults on the integrity of the House, and I urge all of my colleagues to reject this package.  https://lowey.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/lowey-statement-proposed-house-republican-rules-package

A mere 12 hours after proposing to gut the Office of Congressional Ethics (OCE), Republicans heard the overwhelming outrage of the American people and reversed course, leaving the OCE intact. While I am pleased House Republicans had a change of heart, it should not take a public outcry to convince them of the importance of transparency and holding lawmakers accountable for ethics violations.   http://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/03/us/politics/trump-house-ethics-office.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=first-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news
In the 115th Congress, I’m proud to stand and fight for hardworking American families with so many strong Democratic women. #GirlPower

Today’s declassified report on Vladamir Putin’s cybersabotage efforts to support Donald Trump in his bid for the presidency is deeply disturbing. We cannot tolerate any actions that jeopardize the integrity of our democratic institutions. This must transcend politics. It is essential that an independent Congressional commission be immediately established to investigate and report to the American people the full extent of Russia’s espionage.  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/intelligence-chiefs-expected-in-new-york-to-brief-trump-on-russian-hacking/2017/01/06/5f591416-d41a-11e6-9cb0-54ab630851e8_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_trumpbriefing-309pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory&utm_term=.94244d526dfd

I applaud today’s agreement between Governor Cuomo and Entergy to close Indian Point Energy Center. Indian Point has long posed a grave threat to the safety and well-being of those living not only in the Lower Hudson Valley but to the nearly 18 million residents within a 50-mile radius, including New York City. I look forward to working with the Governor to find green solutions to meet New York’s energy needs, keep energy prices low, replace jobs and assist the workforce at Indian Point, support the local economy, and address the proper removal and storage of nuclear waste from the facility.   Since 2002, I have advocated shutting down the plant, and as Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will work to ensure the federal government assists in the safe closure of Indian Point.

Today, Speaker Ryan and the Republican Majority passed their budget--essentially a wish list for President-elect Trump--which repeals the Affordable Care Act making health care inaccessible and more costly for millions, and forces US taxpayers to pay tens of billions of dollars for a wall on the US-Mexico border, all while adding $9.5 trillion to the national debt. These proposals are irresponsible and dangerous, and they will do serious harm to hardworking American families.    Instead of ripping health care away from 30 million Americans and wasting billions of taxpayer dollars on a useless wall, Republicans should work with Democrats on responsible investments to create jobs, improve our healthcare and schools, build roads and bridges and help working families make ends meet.

Today across the country, in community centers, houses of worship, and homes, we gather to remember the life, teachings, and vision of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. In 2017, his legacy and life’s work are as important as ever, and they continue to light America’s path toward becoming a more perfect union.  We must continue to follow Dr. King’s example and strive to live by the principles he fought to uphold. We must continue to work together to make this country a better place than when we found it, regardless of how impossible that goal may seem at times. And we must continue working with all Americans who believe in equality and justice to drive out hate and make Dr. King’s dream a reality.

Today, I was proud to celebrate the life and legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. at events across Rockland and Westchester, including the African American Men of Westchester 16th Annual MLK, Jr. Legacy Youth Awards Luncheon in Tarrytown and the St. Charles AME Zion Church Annual MLK, Jr. Day Commemoration Breakfast in Sparkill, where I was honored to receive the MLK, Jr. Humanitarian Award. As we continue the fight for equality and justice for all Americans, Dr. King’s legacy serves as a powerful reminder of the strength of ordinary citizens to unite against hatred and intolerance.

With respect for our nation’s democratic institutions and the peaceful transfer of power, I am planning to attend the Inauguration. In addition, I will join millions of Americans tomorrow in support of justice and equality for all, respect for women, and leadership that unites – not divides – us.  In Congress, I will keep fighting forcefully with Congressman John Lewis and other colleagues who share my commitment to those ideals. As the highest ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee, it will continue to be my top priority to advance improvements in affordable and accessible health care, gun safety, the right to choose, quality education, and job creation while ensuring accountability for the President-elect.

Today, Donald Trump missed a chance to begin to heal the wounds of a divisive campaign and explain his vision for a bright, inclusive American future.    The time for campaigning is over. Republicans and Democrats must join together in our efforts to make responsible investments in creating jobs, improving healthcare and schools, and helping working families make ends meet.    I congratulate Donald J. Trump on his inauguration as our 45th President. But I will fight tirelessly to hold him to his promise of being a President for all Americans. We must unite to build a more perfect union for our children and grandchildren, with equality and justice for all.  https://lowey.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/lowey-statement-inauguration-donald-trump

In his Inaugural Address, President Trump said he would put ‘America First.’ He can’t do that by reinstating the dangerous Global Gag Rule that marginalizes women around the world and weakens our foreign assistance. That’s why I’ve introduced the Global Health, Empowerment, and Rights (HER) Act to permanently repeal this ill-conceived and draconian Rule.  Women around the world deserve the ability to make healthy choices for themselves and their families. I call on my colleagues from all sides of the aisle to put aside politics and support full and consistent access to family planning and reproductive health services by supporting the Global HER Act. #GlobalGagRule #HER

Today, my bill, the READ Act, passed the House of Representatives. Education is the fundamental tool that empowers girls and boys to increase their economic potential, improve their health outcomes, address cultural biases, participate in their communities, and provide for their families. That’s why the READ Act would prioritize children’s access to education around the world, strengthening our national security and global leadership. I urge my colleagues in the Senate to quickly pass the READ Act, because we cannot build the world we want for ourselves, and for future generations, without making education the center of our efforts.

Rather than heal our divided nation, create jobs or improve access to health care, today, Republicans are taking another step in their tireless quest to drag America back to the Mad Men era by depriving women of their own healthcare decisions. H.R. 7 would roll back women's rights, make comprehensive health insurance more expensive for women, and even penalize small businesses that offer comprehensive health coverage for their employees. But we're not going to take it. America's women demand that Republicans stop this dangerous assault on women's rights.

President Trump’s most recent outrageous executive orders are not just reckless, they are dangerous. In his first week, the President has provided no adequate justification for his multi-billion dollar boondoggle along the US-Mexico border. He will strip federal funding from New York and other ‘sanctuary cities’ that lawfully refuse to bow to his draconian demands. These steps are an affront to our nation’s core values and put American lives at risk.   New York is the top target for terrorist threats in the country. As a result, President Trump’s executive orders will put the City in a budget crisis where it will be unable to fully fund the New York Police Department, counterterrorism operations, and other vital programs that keep New Yorkers safe. It is particularly shameful that President Trump – who professes to be a proud New Yorker – would even consider threatening the security of millions without ensuring the NYPD is reimbursed for the cost of his own protection at Trump Tower.   The President should execute thoughtful policies that keep us safer, not ones that serve simply as costly ideological attacks on the most vulnerable. These directives are counter to who we are as New Yorkers and as Americans. As Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will continue fighting to keep New Yorkers safe, both from terrorism and from attacks on our fundamental values.

Today, on International Holocaust Remembrance Day, we honor the six million Jews murdered for who they were and what they believed. Our solemn vow ‘Never Again’ reaffirms our promise that the legacy and memory of the victims will never be forgotten.  In the last year, public and disgusting displays of intolerance and anti-Semitism have increased across the Lower Hudson Valley and the country. However, we are fortunate to have strong institutions like the Holocaust Museum and Center for Tolerance and Education in Suffern and the Holocaust and Human Rights Education Center (HHREC) in White Plains to remind us of the importance of fighting prejudice with acceptance, violence with peace, and hatred with love.    As we renew our commitment to justice for all people, I find inspiration in HHREC Executive Director Millie Jasper’s call to mark Holocaust Remembrance Day by becoming “upstanders, not bystanders,” in the fight against hatred and bigotry.  http://www.lohud.com/story/news/2017/01/26/holocaust-remembrance-day-remembering-6-million/97041508/

For more than 200 years, the United States has been a haven and symbol of hope for people around the world fleeing persecution, violence, and unspeakable horror. Our Statue of Liberty proudly proclaims, 'Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses.' Yet, on International Holocaust Remembrance Day, President Trump enacted an unconstitutional executive order banning people of a particular religion from entering the United States.   We already have strict security vetting requirements for refugees, and the President's order will not make us safer.  In fact, our enemies will use President Trump's directive for propaganda and recruitment, bolstering their efforts to damage America's global stature and endanger the lives of US citizens at home and abroad. Even Republicans, including Vice President Pence, former Vice President Cheney, and Speaker Ryan, have criticized religious tests for entering our country.   Our nation's most powerful foreign policy tool is our moral leadership. President Trump's action does not live up to America's core values of equality and religious freedom, and he must rescind his executive order immediately.
The 2017 deadline for New Yorkers to sign up for a 2017 health plan is Tuesday, January 31st. To  enroll, visit nystateofhealth.ny.gov or call 1-855-355-5777. #SignUpNY

I’m joining my colleagues from the House and Senate on the steps of the Supreme Court to voice our unified outrage and to demand that President Trump rescind his unconstitutional executive order. I’ll fight to pass the Statue of Liberty Values Act (SOLVe) Act and the No Funds for Unconstitutional Executive Orders Act to prohibit congressionally authorized funds to enforce this illegal directive. #NoBanNoWall

Each day brings a new outrageous act by the Trump Administration. Acting Attorney General Sally Yates was fired overnight by the President for doing her job.   In her refusal to defend the President's illegal religious test for immigrants and refugees, Attorney General Yates did exactly what she swore to do: uphold the constitution and remain loyal to the rule of law. Now more than ever we need principled officials like Sally Yates.  President Trump must stop treating our core values and religious freedoms like reality show plot lines and get serious about the security and economic challenges we face.
It was a pleasure to host King Abdullah of Jordan in the U.S. Capitol to reaffirm the strong partnership between our two countries and to discuss ways to combat extremism around the world.

I am appalled by continued reports of bomb threats against Jewish Community Centers around the country.   I urge community members to remain vigilant at all times, and call on local law enforcement to urgently investigate each incident.  Such hateful intimation targeting Jewish Americans is unacceptable.  We must stand together to condemn such incendiary behavior.
As the head of the Bipartisan Anti-Semitism Task Force, I was honored to host the Honorable Rabbi Lord Jonathan Sacks for an important discussion on stemming the tide of global anti-Semitism.

It has been two years since the fatal Metro-North crash shocked our region, yet the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) still has not released its report on the crash. That's why I wrote the NTSB to ask for an update on when we can expect more information on this deadly collision and on steps we can take to prevent similar tragedies in the future.   Improving rail crossing safety is one of my top priorities, and I've fought to secure new federal investments in rail safety, including more than $5 million for upgrades at 10 different crossings throughout Westchester and Rockland. As Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will continue working hard to ensure that our communities remain safe and secure.  http://www.lohud.com/story/news/transit/2017/02/03/nita-lowey-ntsb-valhalla/97409018/

I’m proud to stand in solidarity with members of our community at the Ossining Unity Vigil who are deeply concerned by the President’s unconstitutional and offensive actions. Hate has no place in the Lower Hudson Valley, in the White House, or anywhere in our great country.

This morning, I was honored to join strong gun safety advocates at the Gun Violence Prevention Forum in Chappaqua. I remain committed to passing commonsense gun safety legislation that will keep our communities safe and protect American lives. Although the political climate is tumultuous, it is our responsibility to act now – regardless of the politics – to spare families the pain that gun violence brings. I will continue working with local legislators and activists to stand up for what is right when it matters the most and keep guns out of the wrong hands.

Unfortunately, today Betsy DeVos was confirmed by the Senate by the closest margin ever for a cabinet nominee. Our children deserve an Education Secretary who does her homework and aces the test, not one who only passes after being graded on a curve.   I join New York families, educators, and a bipartisan group of 50 senators in voicing my deep concern about Devos’ ability to adequately do the job. Her lack of knowledge on education policy and the federal role in promoting the education of students with disabilities, in addition to her extreme desire to gut our nation’s public education system, should have disqualified her from confirmation.  As Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will oversee the Department’s activities and hold Secretary DeVos accountable for providing our students with the education they deserve and our schools with the resources to succeed.

It is a dark day when Republicans are more concerned about silencing the words of Coretta Scott King than protecting the civil rights of Americans.  The Senate’s confirmation of Jeff Sessions as Attorney General is concerning and deeply dangerous. The Justice Department must work aggressively to uphold the Constitution, independently oversee the President, and ensure Americans are equally protected under the law. Regrettably, it is unclear if Jeff Sessions is willing or capable of carrying out these basic job requirements.  As Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will hold the Attorney General and his Justice Department accountable for performing their Constitutional duties to enforce the laws of the United States equally and fairly.

I have a few ideas about what we could do with $21.6 billion that would make families and our economy more secure than Trump's wall: new jobs to build safer roads and bridges, job training and Pell Grants for summer classes, or maybe a cyber wall Putin can't hack to attack our democracy.   http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-immigration-wall-exclusive-idUSKBN15O2ZN

Republicans' proposal to dismantle the Affordable Care Act would jeopardize the financial security of many New York families and put lives at risk. That’s why I hosted a roundtable with Westchester and Rockland constituents, medical providers, hospital administrators, and advocacy organizations to discuss the great strides we have made toward ensuring all Americans have access to affordable, quality health care and the risks of ending the ACA.  Still, we have work to do, and New Yorkers want results, not partisan pandering. As Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will continue to work with my colleagues from all sides of the aisle to find responsible solutions to improve our health care system so that all Americans receive the care they deserve.

President Trump put politics over security with his executive order naming chief strategist, Steve Bannon, to the National Security Council and its Principals Committee. Making matters worse, this order removed the Director of National Intelligence and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from being permanent members of the Principals Committee. Promoting a controversial political aide over policy experts is unprecedented and reckless.  Let me be clear: Mr. Bannon is woefully unqualified to serve as a White House official, let alone on the NSC or the Principals Committee. In his previous role as Chairman of Breitbart News, Mr. Bannon aggressively dispersed inflammatory stories and fake news, and espoused right-wing, anti-Semitic, and xenophobic views that aren’t in line with American values and won’t help keep our country safe.  That’s why I’ve cosponsored H.R. 804, the Protect the National Security Council from Political Interference Act of 2017, which would prohibit Mr. Bannon’s appointment to the NSC, and I’ve called for Bannon to be removed from the White House staff. If the President wants to fulfill his promise of being a leader for all Americans, he must stop putting politics before our national security and remove Mr. Bannon from the NSC and his staff.

Michael Flynn resigned overnight from a job he should never have had. With such close ties to Vladimir Putin and Russia, he should have been disqualified from any job with access to classified material. Instead, President Trump appointed him National Security Advisor, an irresponsible and dangerous decision that appears to have resulted in Flynn subverting American foreign policy.  Flynn’s secret conversation with the Russian government regarding sanctions relief was not simply unethical—it was a potentially illegal act that undermined our national security. I demand an immediate bipartisan, bicameral briefing on the scope of the investigation thus far.  The American people deserve to know when the President learned of Flynn's conversation with the Russian ambassador, and why he appointed a National Security Advisor who was willing to put the interests of Vladimir Putin ahead of those of the United States.

It is disgraceful that President Trump thinks the “real scandal” behind Michael Flynn’s potentially illegal conversation with the Russian government is that news of the phone call leaked. Flynn undermined America’s national security - period. The President learned of Flynn’s actions on January 26, yet the President waited until the American people found out to fire him. I want to know why.   The American people deserve answers. We need to see President Trump’s tax returns, and we need a thorough, independent investigation that gets to the bottom of the links between the President, his Administration, and the Russians once and for all.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/15/us/politics/trump-condemns-leaks-to-news-media-in-a-twitter-flurry.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=a-lede-package-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news&_r=0

We'll see the President in court. I'm proud to join my Democratic colleagues in signing an amicus brief challenging the Trump Administration's unconstitutional travel ban. #NoHateNoFear  http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/15/politics/democrats-amicus-brief-trump-travel-ban/index.html

President Trump is badly missing the mark by investigating so-called “low-life leakers." Instead we need to investigate his Administration’s inappropriate and potentially illegal contact with Russian intelligence officials. The American People will not be distracted by President Trump’s smoke and mirrors ploy. We must uphold the sovereignty of the United States and demand a full and independent investigation into these activities.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/16/us/politics/trump-russia-leaks-twitter.html

Today, President Trump responded to an important question about bomb threats to numerous Jewish Community Centers in recent weeks by interrupting the reporter to call the question “unfair.” What is truly unfair and deeply disturbing is the Trump Administration’s deafening silence at the continued rise of anti-Semitic incidents across the country, leaving Jewish families fearful for their safety. The Jewish community deserves nothing less than a swift, comprehensive response from President Trump and his Administration on their plans to investigate these dangerous threats. Hatred and violence has no place in the United States.

Judith of White Plains has a son born with congenital heart disease, but the ACA prevents insurance companies from discriminating against people with pre-existing conditions so he is guaranteed access to care. If health reform is repealed, she’s extremely worried that his heart anomaly will preclude his access to health insurance, not to mention limit his employment options, and keep him out of work.  Repealing the ACA would strip insurance from 2.7 million New Yorkers and cost 130,000 jobs in the Lower Hudson Valley. That’s why we have to #ProtectOurCare. Tell me your story about why health reform can’t be repealed at Lowey.House.gov/ShareYourStory.

The protections provided by the Affordable Care Act help keep Cathy from Tappan, who lives with Leukemia, and her family safe. Thanks to the ACA, they no longer need to worry about hitting an arbitrary cap on lifetime expenses for cancer treatments, and her Autistic daughter can stay on the family’s insurance plan if her conditions prevent her from full-time employment. If the ACA is repealed, Cathy wonders how she will continue to afford her treatments and ensure her daughter gets the care she desperately needs.   That’s one more reason we have to #ProtectOurCare. Help protect the progress we’ve made – share your story online at Lowey.House.gov/ShareYourStory.

It’s #ProtectOurCare national day of action. I’m protecting our care by standing strong in Washington against efforts to throw our health care system into chaos by repealing the Affordable Care Act Only. Just a few years ago, millions of Americans across the country did not have access to affordable, quality health care. A single trip to the hospital could deplete a family's life savings; one illness could cost them their home. Now more than 20 million Americans across the country, over 930,000 of them in New York, have been insured through the Affordable Care Act, many for the first time.   We cannot afford to lose the progress we’ve made. Instead we must work together to improve our health care system so that all Americans have access to the quality, affordable care they need.

Last week, I spoke out on the Floor of the House against Republicans’ shameful attempts to restrict comprehensive family planning and preventive health services. Congressional Republicans’ war on women must stop, and I will continue fighting fiercely against every outrageous attack on women’s rights.

The ongoing bomb threats to Jewish Community Centers across the country and today's threat to the Anti-Defamation League's national headquarters are unprecedented and horrifying. That's why I sent a letter to Homeland Security Secretary Kelly, Attorney General Sessions, and FBI Director Comey with 157 of my colleagues urging Department of Homeland Security and Department of Justice to describe what specific steps are being taken to deter and prosecute instances of telephone terrorism. We cannot sit idly by while communities are threatened with bigoted violence and hate.

I am outraged that the Senate confirmed Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to head the Environmental Protection Agency just 24 hours after a federal judge ruled that Oklahoma must turn over thousands of emails related to Pruitt’s communications with fossil fuel companies. This information is central to whether Pruitt is fit to lead the agency, considering he accepted over $300,000 from the oil and gas special interests. As Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will hold Administrator Pruitt and the Trump Administration accountable for ensuring our families and communities have access to clean air and water.

I was proud to meet with strong and passionate local activists from Peekskill and Croton to discuss how I'm fighting the Trump Administration's hateful and potentially illegal actions. Hardworking American families need real solutions, not offensive and dangerous policies that only serve to divide our nation. As Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Committee, I will fight to create jobs and protect our national security while holding the President accountable for every proposed cut and every unconstitutional proposal.

A bomb threat was made today against the Jewish Community Center on the Hudson in Tarrytown. My office has been in contact with local police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to offer all necessary support to the ongoing investigation and to bring the criminals responsible for this horrifying act of terrorism to justice. We will not allow hatred, bigotry, or anti-Semitic violence to terrorize our families or our community.

I am proud to have White Plains resident Noah Buyon as my guest to President Trump’s speech before a Joint Session of Congress tonight. Noah suffers from Crohn’s Disease, and if Republicans follow through on their plans to repeal the Affordable Care Act, Noah’s pre-existing condition might prevent him from being able to secure insurance coverage once he turns 26. Noah is one of the thousands of Lower Hudson Valley residents who rely on the protections provided by the Affordable Care Act, and I hope that Noah’s brave decision to share his story will help Republicans realize the dangers of destroying the progress we've made toward ensuring all Americans have affordable, quality health care.   https://lowey.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/lowey-brings-constituent-protected-affordable-care-act-joint-session

President Trump’s speech tonight fell short on the positive, inclusive agenda that would unite our nation and on solutions to America’s most pressing challenges.  While the President acknowledged the 100 anti-Semitic bomb threats made against over 60 Jewish Community Centers and schools across the country, including two in Westchester, it is not enough. He must show a real commitment to protecting and defending the dignity and humanity of Americans of all faiths, backgrounds, and identities with swift and strong action.  The President made promises we already know he can’t keep.  To expand access and make health care even more affordable, we need to expand on the progress of the Affordable Care Act. Americans like my guest tonight, a college student with Crohn’s disease who fears he won’t be able to find or afford health care and stay healthy enough to hold down a job in a few years, are rightfully worried. The only thing Republicans seem to agree on when it comes to the ACA is repealing it, without a plan to address the chaos that would create.  The President can’t protect working families with his proposal to dramatically increase military spending at the expense of programs working Americans rely on to survive and get ahead. Let me be clear: our national defense is paramount, and we need to support our women and men in uniform during and after their service. But our success also depends on ensuring that children have access to the education they need to compete in a 21st century economy, that all Americans receive quality, affordable health care, that we invest in creating good jobs and training Americans to fill them, that families across the United States have access to clean water and air.   Our security and our economy rely on strong leadership in the international community that is undermined by policies like the President’s unconstitutional Muslim ban and his wasteful $21 billion dollar border wall. These valuable federal dollars could instead be invested in policies proven to keep our communities secure. Cutting foreign aid would also undermine stability around the world, and even military experts agree that’s a bad strategy.    The American people deserve consistent leadership from their President, grounded in dignity and respect for all people. President Trump has yet to demonstrate that he understands the solemn responsibility of his job.

I am a proud cosponsor of Representative Jerry Nadler’s Resolution of Inquiry that would direct the Department of Justice to immediately provide all information related to the investigation into President Trump and his associates’ conflicts of interest, ethical violations, and connections with Russia. Shamefully, the Republicans on the House Judiciary Committee yesterday voted this Resolution down. The American people deserve answers about the President’s shady ties to Vladamir Putin’s Russia, and I demand Republicans allow this Resolution be brought to the Floor and voted on by the full House of Representatives.   https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2017/02/28/republicans-vote-down-attempt-to-force-debate-on-trump-russia-allegations/?utm_term=.236011b4a957

I call on Attorney General Jeff Sessions to resign. I am deeply troubled that he appears to have lied under oath in front of the Senate Judiciary Committee regarding his ties to Russian officials. We now know that he met with a Russian Ambassador at the same time he was campaigning for Donald Trump, which is shocking and unacceptable.  Last month, I sent a letter to the Attorney General expressing my deep concern with the Trump Administration’s ties to Russia during the campaign and after the election. I called for his recusal and for the appointment of special counsel to conduct an independent investigation. This has become a bipartisan call, as both House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy and Oversight Chairman Jason Chaffetz have called for the Attorney General’s recusal as well.  However, these recent revelations make clear that recusal is not enough. The Attorney General is the highest law enforcement official in the country and must be truly independent.  He must resign and a bipartisan commission should be established to maintain trust in our law enforcement.  https://lowey.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/lowey-calls-resignation-attorney-general-jeff-sessions

I was proud to join the other co-chairs of the Bipartisan Taskforce for Combating Anti-Semitism in calling on President Trump to take swift and specific actions against the horrific wave of anti-Semitic bomb threats against Jewish Community Centers and schools. The Department of Justice must have access to the necessary resources to fully investigate these threats and anti-Semitic acts, and they must coordinate with other law enforcement agencies to respond quickly and aggressively to future threats to the Jewish community.

I hosted a roundtable with local Jewish leaders today at the Jewish Community Center on the Hudson in Tarrytown to discuss the horrifying threats against JCCs in Westchester and across the country. As Co-Chair of the Bipartisan Taskforce for Combating Anti-Semitism, I wrote President Trump to demand that the Department of Justice use its full power to immediately bring the perpetrators of these crimes to justice. Anti-Semitic violence or hatred in any form have absolutely no place in our community and will not be tolerated by the federal government.

I wrote a letter to the New York Times today because it is our responsibility as legislators to hear our constituents, advance their financial and physical security, improve communities and build for the future — not to rubber stamp the dangerous whims of the president. It is time for Congress to act like the separate and coequal branch that we are.   https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/opinion/let-congress-be-coequal-not-a-rubber-stamp.html

The American people will not be fooled by the Trump Administration’s outrageous attempt to bait and switch one unconstitutional Muslim ban for another. As the White House officials promised, today’s executive action is simply a rewording with the same intent and impact.  Let me be clear: this will not make America safer. It will corrode our moral leadership around the world and be used as propaganda by those who want to do us harm. Even the President’s own Department of Homeland Security found that citizenship is an “unlikely indicator” for identifying potential terrorist threats.  Discriminating against those in need based on nationality or religion is contrary to our nation’s fundamental values of freedom, justice, and equality for all. It’s not who we are and we will not accept it. I will continue working with my colleagues to fight against attacks on our basic values and find solutions that truly keep Americans safe.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/us/politics/travel-ban-muslim-trump.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=a-lede-package-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news

Now we know why Republicans didn’t want anyone to read their health care plan. More than seven years since the Affordable Care Act passed, and with the uninsured rate at record lows, Trumpcare will threaten health coverage for millions of Americans, increase premiums, jeopardize the retirement security for middle-class families, attack women’s health, and diminish health coverage for the most vulnerable among us. It will force working families to pay more for less, and the Republican game of hide and seek with this bill conveniently covered up how much all of this chaos will cost.  We cannot return to a time when American families lived in fear that a single illness or trip to the hospital could bankrupt them. We should be working to provide more Americans quality, affordable care, not forcing working families to pay more for less coverage. I will continue to fight every attempt to rip health care away from millions of Americans and destroy the progress we have made.  https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/06/us/politics/affordable-care-act-obamacare-health.html

A CSX train carrying hazardous materials that was scheduled to travel through Rockland derailed today in Newburgh. Yet again the quick and decisive action of our first responders demonstrated that these brave women and men are so critical to protecting our communities. This derailment is part of a disturbing pattern of accidents involving freight trains carrying hazardous materials through densely populated areas. We must build on the progress we have made to improve rail safety and decrease risks to our communities.

Today we celebrate International Women’s Day by recognizing the importance of empowering women and girls around the world through universal access to quality educational programs, economic opportunities, and health care. That’s why I introduced the READ Act, which calls for a comprehensive US strategy to improve educational opportunities and address gender barriers to school attendance, retention, and completion in the poorest areas of the world. In 2015, 36,252 Americans lost their lives due to a firearm. That’s unacceptable. I offered an amendment to the FY2018 Labor, Health and Human Services appropriations bill today that would provide $10 million for the CDC to conduct research on gun violence and injury prevention. Why wouldn’t we do everything we can to equip policymakers with the information to address one of the leading causes of death? I’ll continue the fight for common-sense gun reform.

Senate Republicans have managed to propose a plan that is even more morally bankrupt than Trumpcare. The CBO has just confirmed that their repeal-and-delay plan would leave 32 million more Americans uninsured and would double premiums by 2026. I urge Republicans to abandon this ill-conceived plan and work with Democrats to achieve common-sense solutions to expand access to quality, affordable health care.

Last night, I offered an amendment to the FY2018 State and Foreign Operations Appropriations Bill to strike both the expansion of the dangerous, anti-woman Global Gag Rule (GGR) and the ban on funding for the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA). Every member of the U.S. military deserves our profound respect and gratitude for their sacrifices and service. This evening, a group of Senate Republicans announced that they will only vote for the “skinny” Republican health care bill, which would gut important parts of the Affordable Care Act, if the bill does not become law. I commend the FDA for its commitment to lower the amount of nicotine in cigarettes and decrease the number of Americans addicted to tobacco.  However, this is not enough.  Today’s announcement by the FDA to delay regulations on new tobacco products will give the tobacco industry four more years to roll back the bipartisan Tobacco Control Act.  FDA is opening Pandora’s box in allowing a new generation of young people to get hooked on nicotine delivery devices, such as e-cigarettes, and Americans will pay the cost for decades to come.

Today is Black Women’s Equal Pay Day, the day that marks when African-American women’s wages catch up to what men were paid in the previous year. There are serious, significant impediments for women who do not receive equal pay for equal work. It’s time to give women and families the economic security that comes with equal pay for equal work.

New York Medical College is a leading biomedical research institution, and these federal funds will help advance its groundbreaking research. This morning, I brought together local superintendents, medical experts, substance abuse prevention workers and advocates, and students for a roundtable discussion on e-cigarette use among teens.   Today’s meeting was an excellent opportunity to discuss serious concerns about teenage e-cigarette use and to gain important insights that will help us combat youth smoking.   Five years ago, parents would have worried about their kids taking in too much sugar from a steady diet of Fruit Loops, Gummy Bears, and Swedish Fish. Today, we’re worried that vaping products with those flavors will expose them to dangerous, addictive chemicals.   We can’t afford to lose another generation to the harms of nicotine addiction.

I’m pleased that the U.S. Senate has passed my Reinforcing Education Accountability in Development (READ) Act, bipartisan legislation that would enhance transparency and accelerate the impact of U.S. basic education programs around the world in order to help countries address the more than 263 million children and youth who are out of school. There is no greater force multiplier in foreign aid than education. Prioritizing education around the world will not only help students learn to read and write—it will ultimately help protect vulnerable children from poverty, disease, hunger, and even extremism. Simply put, we cannot build the world we want for ourselves, and for future generations, without making education the center of our efforts.

A White Plains constituent contacted our office because he needed an earnings statement from the Social Security Administration (SSA) in order to obtain his pension. I take great pride in helping my constituents navigate federal agencies. Those who committed hateful violence and domestic terrorism, taking one woman's life while injuring and threatening many more, must be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. It is the responsibility of all Americans, including our highest elected officials, to reject this hate that engenders fear and perpetuates violence in our communities and give it no cover through weak criticisms, false equivalencies, and complacency.

The President’s heinous comments since the violence in Charlottesville have stained the office of the presidency.  Today, I became an original cosponsor of legislation to censure the President. It’s unacceptable to allow false equivalencies between the white supremacist and neo-Nazi protesters and the counterprotesters who stood up for equal rights, justice, and freedom. It’s unacceptable that the President employs officials associated with hate groups. As Ranking Member on the House Appropriations Committee, I will continue to fight against any efforts—including President Trump’s Fiscal Year 2018 budget—to cut medical research. We must join together and support a future where science, the environment, and public health are a priority.

I was honored to join Governor Andrew Cuomo, along with local elected officials, at a ceremony today to mark the opening of the first span of the Tappan Zee Bridge replacement, the Governor Mario M. Cuomo Bridge. The Tappan Zee Bridge replacement is one of the most urgently needed and important infrastructure projects in the nation, and today marked another important step toward providing much-needed relief for commuters and strengthening a critical link in our region’s infrastructure system. I’m proud to have supported Governor Cuomo’s vision and leadership and to have helped secure $1.6 billion in federal funding through a historic TIFIA loan to make this new bridge a reality for the Lower Hudson Valley. Our state and regional economy depends on reliable transportation infrastructure, and this innovative solution will continue to spur economic growth for years to come. It is fitting that this great system of infrastructure will be named after Mario Cuomo, a great governor of the state of New York.
I spoke with News 12 Westchester about the need to increase federal investments in biomedical research so we can end cancer once and for all. These investments must always be a bipartisan issue.
President Trump's directive banning transgender military recruits is an insult to the valor and heroism of every American in uniform.
My thoughts and prayers are with all those affected by Hurricane Harvey. And my deepest thanks to the brave first responders working tirelessly to keep their communities safe.

President Trump's pardon of Sheriff Arpaio is a flagrant abuse of his pardoning powers and shows complete disrespect for the rule of law. Sheriff Arpaio was found guilty of violating the constitutional rights of Latinos and should be held accountable. With this pardon, the president has sent a message that racial profiling and discrimination by law enforcement will not only go unpunished, it will be rewarded by this Administration.

Today, Women’s Equality Day, we honor the courageous men and women who fought for and secured the right of women to vote. In the 97 years since the adoption of the 19th Amendment, women have made outstanding progress, reaching the highest levels of government, business, science, and education. But more work remains, from securing equal pay for equal work to expanding economic opportunities for women to ending discrimination. I am committed to this fight, as I have been throughout my time in Congress.   Years ago, along with six of my colleagues, I stormed up the Senate steps to demand the confirmation vote on Justice Clarence Thomas be delayed so that Professor Anita Hill’s account of sexual harassment could be heard. The scene was later recreated in HBO’s Confirmation. While we’ve come so far, we must continue to storm along to achieve true gender equality.

I strongly condemn the Tehran Appeals Court’s decision to uphold the unjust convictions of Siamak and Baquer Namazi. This attempt will not work, and the court’s decision only further erodes Iranian credibility on the Namazi case. President Trump’s decision to end the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program is immoral and wrong. DREAMers, who were brought to the United States as children, are Americans in the eyes of their communities. They grow up alongside our children, have graduated from school or served in the military, pay billions in taxes, and contribute to our economic growth and competitiveness.  Today’s announcement continues a pattern of anti-immigrant actions and policies by the Republican Party. In an undemocratic and underhanded move, majority leadership stripped from an upcoming spending package a bipartisan provision, introduced by Appropriations Democrats, that makes DACA recipients eligible for federal jobs.   It is past time for comprehensive immigration reform that gives these young people a path to citizenship while reforming our nation’s broken immigration laws, keeping families together, and protecting our economy and our borders. http://bit.ly/2xMkQsV

Every member of our community deserves protection from domestic abuse, sexual assault, and violence in any form. It is great news that Rockland County will have more resources to ensure that women and children who have suffered from violence receive the support and safety they need and deserve.

I strongly support this effort to protect young immigrants from deportation by the Trump Administration, and I am proud that my home state of New York is among those challenging the president’s unjust decision. These young people are Americans in every way but on paper, and they deserve to remain in America, the only country they know as home. An immediate legislative solution is needed to protect these young immigrants from deportation, and I call on Republican leadership to bring the DREAM Act up for a vote.

Today the House passed a bill to provide relief for the communities and families affected by Hurricane Harvey, who remain in our thoughts and prayers. And I expect a much larger request from the administration, including funding to mitigate damage from future storms, similar to funding passed after Sandy for resiliency efforts to ensure that future generations can mitigate the damage from storms that have grown in intensity.

While Congress has worked to require passenger railroads to implement technology that will prevent rail accidents and save lives, there is still more to be done to address human factors that can contribute to fatal derailments. My amendment, which unanimously passed the U.S. House, would make a necessary investment in rail safety, helping ensure that critical safety personnel are capable of carrying out their responsibilities. This amendment is a major achievement, and I am pleased that both my Republican and Democratic colleagues recognized the need to move it forward. We have taken an important step to prevent future rail accidents and save lives.

The Trump Administration’s decision to roll back Title IX protections shows its utter disregard for survivors of sexual assault. Sixteen years after the September 11th terror attacks, our hearts are heavy in remembrance of the lives taken from us too soon.  That day was one of unimaginable tragedy and unspeakable terror, senseless loss and profound grief.   But it was also a day of common purpose, shared humanity, selflessness, courage and sacrifice.  We will never forget those whose lives were cut short, including the brave first responders who saved countless lives, often at the expense of their own.   We will never forget the rescue and recovery volunteers who also sacrificed their own lives, who worked at the site for weeks and months, and became sick in the years that followed, and we will always remember their loved ones.   And we will never forget the ordinary people, like Welles Crowther of Nyack, “the man in the red bandana,” who did extraordinary things, sacrificing themselves so that others could live.     The names of the nearly 3,000 men, women, and children killed that September day are not just inscribed on the bronze parapets at the 9/11 memorial in New York City, their lives are etched in history.   On this and every anniversary of 9/11, we are reminded of our common purpose and solemn responsibilities: to care for the responders still sick today with illnesses related to their rescue work at Ground Zero; to adapt our counterterrorism efforts to the changing face of terrorism abroad so that it never reaches our shores again; to give our law enforcement the resources to prevent and prepare to respond to attacks; and last, but not least, to hold the victims and heroes of September 11th and their families forever in our hearts.

Republicans have not made a good faith effort at extending CHIP, even though a one-year extension would cost $14 billion, about one percent of the cost of the tax bill. Sixteen states will exhaust CHIP funding by the end of January, and three-quarters of states, including New York, will exhaust all funds by the end of March.
